Update: went back with friends. They loved it, too.  Recommended: vegetarian appetizer platter $5.95 --- what's with these great prices?
author: Tony S.

description:
BEWARE OF OVERCHARGES & DOUBLE-CHARGES!  Several of the reviews on here talk about how much more expensive the prices are at Clay Oven.  Maybe they've just been scammed like we have.

We just returned from our second visit, and it's not likely that there will be a third.  We specifically asked for ONE order each of pappadum, rice, and  naan.  When TWO orders of each came out, we sent back the second.  However, this was conveniently forgotten when the bill came (just like the first visit).  We were also constantly being "upsold" on everything in a very annoying way.  Too many expensive suggestions & add-ons.  Finally, we were overcharged on one appetizer and one entree.  I'm sure that was a "mistake" too.

Watch out especially for the waiter with the bad hair color (reddish).

We felt like we were treated like dollar signs instead of patrons. (By the way, the best service we ever had at an Indian restaurant was at Sultan on Taylor Street.  Great food, too.)
author: melissa o.

description: I like the food at this place even though it's pricey for Indian. However, tonight, not feeling well, I decided to order delivery. I've been waiting for nearly two hours. Even if it's Friday, two hours is outrageous when I live five minutes away.
author: Zsuzsanna M.

description: With the end of Bombay restaurant's lunch buffet, I was happy to walk by a sign for India Clay Oven's lunch buffet on Church. There seems to be a dearth of these lunchtime options in SF, vs south bay, where I have my favorite haunts. Buffet is $9.99, and featured lamb curry, saag paneer and chicken tikka masala, and hot naan at your table. They charge $2 for a cup of chai, and I was surprised there weren't any daal choices- yellow and brown lentils are always fave buffet items for me. Service was adequate but not very friendly. Personally, the chicken tikka masala is better at spicy bite on cortland and mission,and I prefer the $1 chai at pakwan, or better yet to have it included as part of the buffet. Still I'm happy to know there's a buffet option close by, with reasonable prices.
author: Monty L.

description:
I cannot believe that this place has gotten the "Best of the Bay" awards.  It is very average Indian food.  I ordered Chicken Tiki, Mater Paneer and some nan just to try this place out.  I ordered for delivery - delivery took a little too long.  The food was fine but, I was expecting more because of the awards it had received.  I think it is quite pricey for what you get as well.

I have had a lot of Indian food in different cities and this by my tastes is only average.
author: Chris B.

description: I finally found place to go to if I want to feed my Indian fix.  The buffet spread was fine.  Everything tasted good including the desserts.  What blew me away was the ambience.  The place was nicely decorated with a lot of attention to details in the table setting.  It looks like they use real china for their plates!  For the inexpensive buffet lunch price, well worth it.
author: May B.

description:
There are three Indian restaurant options for folks living in lower Noe Valley - Zantes, Spicy Bite and now Clay Oven. Clay Oven has probably the best dining experience. 

The interior decor is beautiful with artistic murals on the walls. The staff is friendly and courteous. Old hindi music tunes. Oh yes...there's also the food.

For a vegetarian like me, options are bountiful in Indian restaurants. I especially love the Aloo Parathas (Pancakes stuffed with spicy, mashed potato). I have made so many trips for them here that the chef must have surely perfected the art. They have a good spread for buffet. Love the Okra curry and the dal (lentils). Their masala chai has slices of ginger in it and their after-mint/fennel top quality.

This place is still undiscovered, I have found myself being the only person in the restaurant on several occasions. I want this place to thrive so I can continue to eat here. 

CONS
Indian Pickle - $2. Whaaa?
author: Maneesh S.

description:
Yes, this place is expensive. Dinner for four cost $90. Yikes! We would've paid half as much at, say, Al Hamra or Pakwan on 16th Street in the Mission. However, we enjoyed the atmosphere, and the food, while not the best in the world, was all right. Skimpy portion sizes.

Papadum: Should've been crispier, seemed slightly soggy. Naan: Cookied unevently? Not moist 'n' fluffy enough. Rice: Good, served in individual copper pails, but $2.25 a pop is beyond ridiculous. Chicken tikka masala: Properly yummy sauce, not nearly enough meat, even worse than usual (few places provide enough, really). Fish tikka masala: Delicious! With enough fish! Best dish of the evening. Bengan bharta: Nice texture, fairly one-dimensional. Aloo saag: Ditto.

We had to wait a while before someone came to take our order. However, at the end, a man kept coming by and checking to see if we'd paid. And the staff were very eager to sell us more beer.

Pluses: It's near home. They deliver. The food is mostly okay. Minuses: Price! General attitude.
author: Tara M.

description:
We went to the Clay Oven on Church Street for dinner on New Years Day.

Food:

Since we were eating with my parents we asked for mild spiciness.  My partner & I ordered the Clay Oven dinner which had papadum & samosa appetizers, tandoori chicken, chicken tikka masala, boti kabab (lamb), saag paneer (spinach & cheese), naan, rice, keer, kulfi &  chai.  My parents ordered prawn biriyani (no raita), saag lamb, rice and basket of assorted naan.

Everything was good and the presentation was quaint.  Some of the dishes were placed on top of the candles already on the table.  The rice had sweet peas in them and was served in a mini-bucket with handle.

Environment:
Music was too loud.  Walls have beautiful murals on them, but reflect sound too well.  Even with the music, we could hear many sounds from the kitchen.  Very cozy.  Some of the chairs are comfortable.  Some are not.

Service:  
Our waiters were very attentive.

Bar:
A very small bar situated in the back on the side.  There were a few patrons who sat there.  My father and I had a beer so that might not be enough to warrant a complete review of the bar.

Overall, I think it was a nice experience and we might go back again.  I can't comment on the delivery or take out service.  If we do order delivery, I will add to this review.
author: David J.

description: I live right near this place and decided to check it out a few months ago. I can't believe I went this long without coming here! The food is great and the staff is so incredibly nice. They make an attempt to get to know their customers and within a few visits they already recognized me and were very personable. Highly recommended!
author: Ashley S.

description: I love my neighborhood Indian Restaurant.  Babu takes my take out order and is always so gracious and friendly.  The Chicken Tikka Masala is delicious and full of flavor.  Bhindi Bhaji Masala (okra cooked with chopped onions, tomatoes and spices) is one of my favorite.  Delivery is prompt and food is HOT!
author: Elizabeth F.

description:
Pretty standard Indian Food.
They have a lunch special, around $8, the same price as a buffet at other Indian places.
Service is prompt and thorough enough to ask, "How spicy?"
My Coconut Lamb turned out to be a bit over salted.
The sauce was not as complex as I would have liked.
I'll have to explore this restaurant a bit more.
It has potential.
author: Geordie E.

description:
Despite the fact that there are 2 Indian restaurants within 2 blocks from my house, I was very excited to see Indian Clay Oven move into to the hood. The first time I went there, they had just opened and they didn't have everything dialed in yet. The food was cold, and the salad greens were brown. I would have given it a 1 star rating but I decided to give it another chance. I am so glad I did! The food was piping hot and spicy - just the way I like it.  My friend got a vegetable dinner plate - it was huge, no way one person could eat it all. I got the chicken tikka masala (creature of habit, I always get that). The only thing I didn't love that I ordered was the rice pudding - better to skip it and buy a pint of something on the way home.

One small nit - I am really not picky when it comes to wine but the wine list was awful, but then again  I don't think i have ever been to an indian food place with a decent wine selection.
author: Lynn G.

description: Gave it a second chance, they fixed their problems. Nicest service too, glad they are good again.
author: G. John E.

description:
Good but not great, zantes & spicy bite ( bernal ) bombay  (castro) seem to be a bit better in taste and cost. This place is so close to my house, I can't complain too much.  The chicken tikka masala was ok, but the chicken Korma, was so much better. The masala had like shredded pieces of chicken, whereas the korma had chunks of tandori chicken
The prices were more expensive than their competitors, about 2.00 more a dish than the others.  

Also the biggest disappointment, their Nan was about 5 inches wide! Most Nan I've had are about a foot wide, their Nan was too tiny! About the size of a pancake!!!!
author: Pug P.

description:
Confession:  My rating system sucks.  Maybe your does too.

I gave Spiciy Bite four stars -- as does most everyone -- but I would never eat-in there.  At Clay Oven on the other hand, I've eaten in twice, liked the food, had good service, thought price was right... I'm giving it four stars too even though it's much more than my "to go" place a few blocks away.

Try the Kashmir Nan.  It reads as if it's a "Pop Tart Nan" but it works like a chutney.  It's good.

In two visits we didn't have any misses w/ Cicken Tikka Masala, Tandoori Prawns, Aloo Gobi, Saag Paneer, Lamb Curry.

We ordered everthing medium hot on both occaisions and didn't really find much heat there so think "hot" if you want to be cautious between bites.
author: don d.

description:
My husband and I are not experts on Indian food, but we found our appetizers, condiments and main dishes acceptable but not out of this world. We found the waiters to be sweet and attentive and we liked the atmosphere.

Then we ordered coconut ice cream to share for dessert. And as we ate, we both looked up and said, "I think this is vanilla ice cream with shredded coconut on it..." We called the waiter over and showed him. He said, "yes it is vanilla." (Actually a 'cookies and cream'-type ice cream). He took it into the kitchen and about 10 minutes later, the manager came out and said that he would be taking it off our bill, but that it was really 'mixed coconut and vanilla ice-cream'. A lie. A bald-faced lie. He was trying to save face by not admitting their 'mistake'. And I use the word mistake generously, because it's obvious that they were just trying to pull the wool over our eyes. Weird and very disappointing. I couldn't wait to get it off my chest on Yelp!
author: Ellen R.

description:
Nice and quiet place for lunch. My vegetable korma was too salty. It would be much better without so much salt. My friend wanted to get something that was not on the menu, and they were able to accommodate her request and were very nice about it. 

You need to request a separate lunch special menu if you're interested. Unless you ask for it, they will just give you a regular menu.
author: Mia D.

description:
I have not dined in at the restaurant - but, somewhat accidentally ordered delivery from this location. I was trying to order from the new West Portal location - but, apparently, they don't have delivery yet.

In any case - I used the online ordering option - which I love (for some reason, I just dont like using the phone). The site is a little clunky - not the best design - but, it got my order, and i received it pretty quickly (within an hour on a sat. night) - especially considering that I don't live all that close.

I think the prices were reasonable and the food was good. Not outstanding - but, definitely good ... and, the convenience of delivery when you have two small children is awesome.

I will be ordering again.
author: Karen G.

description:
When a restaurant is called Clay Oven, my instinct is to try the tandoori, of course. And, our virgin night of take-out at Clay Oven did not disappoint completely as in some reviews below. We got the Tandoori mixed grill (it took 40 minutes to deliver, which is typical on a Friday night even in Noe). 

Each piece of shrimp, lamb and chicken was succulent, well-flavoured and I would definitely order this again. It was pricey if you go by the Indian-hole-in-the-wall standard of Pakwan and Shalimar which is supposed to be cheap. My one complaint for take-out was the very mediocre samosas which I consider a staple of Indian fast food/chaat/snacks. The dough was not crisp and came in on the bland side including the filling. 

Which brings me to my observation during sit-down dinner last night: I was excited to see Palak Pakora (spinach fried in chickpea batter), but disappointed at the outcome. I really think that Clay Oven needs a new fryer or hotter fryer or something to that end. Even the Poori (a fried whole wheat bread) resembled a hot yet soggy pita. Not impressive. Cheese Naan was ok, but not enough cheese to hit me with that "homemade cheese" goodness.

Our dishes: Shrimp Tikka Masala and traditional Lamb Curry were fair. The tikka sauce wasn't as rich as I usually have had, and the Lamb Curry wasn't spicy enough for my companion. Granted, he likes things spiced up, but when I tasted it it was very one-dimensional. Rice was good and came in the cute copper buckets--a highlight for my aesthetic sense. I ordered a kulfi for dessert, and it was very traditional which means while tasty and authentically tasty, it came sliced in blocks in a small bowl with spoon, a little difficult to eat at first. Once it began to melt, the nutty, creaminess endured and finished the meal well. Dinner for two with beer and wine was still $80 after tip.

I live a block away so of course I'll be back. It's a decent addition to the nabe for me since I'm not real fond of the Thai place across the street.
author: E L.

description:
I was psyched to see an Indian restaurant open in the neighborhood, even though there are two other Indian restaurants just a few blocks away on Mission. 

I came here for an early (5 p.m.) Christmas dinner, so the restaurant was empty. By the time I left, the restaurant had filled out more with some larger parties.

I ordered the Garden Thali, which consisted of saag paneer, a vegetable samosa, yellow dal, papadam, rice, nan, raita, kheer & chai for $14.95. Everything was quite tasty - I liked everything that was served, especially the saag paneer.

The atmosphere was nice - clean & crisp interior, friendly staff. 

I'd go back again, mostly likely for lunch.
author: Sean G.

description: DO NOT ORDER TAKE OUT FROM THEM.  Twice in a row we have been burned by them.  They say 40 minutes but it takes 1 1/2 hour to 2 ours for the food to arrive. both times we tried.  The second time we ended up cancelling and ordering pizza.  Sounds like the food is good if you eat in the restaurant but do not trust or believe there delivery estimate.  Way better and more timely Indian take out here in San Fran.
author: Stef S.

description: I ordered take out from them earlier today at 12:56pm, and I have still yet to receive my order.  I have checked twice with eat 24, and both times they checked with the restaurant and they said they would be at  my house within a few minutes...that was 30 min ago.  I am canceling my order and will never order from them again this is ridiculous, especially because I live several blocks away.
author: Kristen M.

description:
Pretty solid food here on our first visit. Clay Oven in San Mateo was always a favorite in high school but the other San Francisco locations have been a mixed bag (India Clay Oven received high marks for papadum and some of the best chutney around, but disappointed with a chewy, gamey lamb dish; India Garden had great ambiance but lackluster food; Tandori Mahal just never really impressed). Despite the less than stellar track record, we were enticed by the entertainment rewards coupon and the convenient proximity of the Noe Valley location to give the Clay Oven folks another shot. Although not blown away, we were pleasantly surprised with the latest addition to the Clay Oven franchise.

The samosas were nice and fresh, but the chutney (at least the to-go chutney) was not nearly as good as the stuff that had wowed us at India Garden a while ago. The navrattam korma was fine. Nothing special but reasonably fresh tasting and better than renditions we'd had at India Garden and Tandoori Mahal. The Boti Kabab was the hit of the night though. At $12.95, this dish is a bit pricey for the serving size, but was really excellent. Perfectly cooked, tender, juicy, and exquisitely flavored.

I don't know what accounts for the inconsistency in the Clay Oven franchise, but hopefully the Noe Valley location will keep up the good work. A little pricier than Zante's and overall, pretty similar quality. We'll likely be back for the nice atmosphere and that amazing lamb dish. Definitely a nice addition to Noe Valley, and worth a try if you're in the neighborhood, but not worth a special trip, with the wealth of other excellent Indian food in other parts of the City.
author: Brian H.

description:
My fiancee and I love Indian and have been in the neighborhood for years without having tried Clay Oven.  We finally ordered delivery tonight.  Most of the reviews here about the price are pretty spot on--it's a little pricey for what you get; after tax and tip, we were in about $45 for nan, samosas, rice, chicken tikka masala, and saag paneer.  The food was good but not incredible--I'd put it on the same level as Pakwan.  But when you compare the cheapness of Pakwan's prices to Clay Oven, it's no competition.  Delivery literally took 20 minutes, so I was quite impressed and they earned points for that.  The portions were also on par with what I'm used to for Indian food, so I'm not sure where the other complaints about that are coming from.  All in all, fine, but nothing to write home about.

Perhaps a word of warning: I love spicy food, but my fiancee not so much, so I went with medium for the spice level for our two main dishes.  Maybe I was off my game tonight or they misheard the order, but man, medium was definitely all the spice I needed!
author: Chris L.

description:
Ok, this is probably the blandest indian food I have ever eaten, and I grew up in Sweden where indian food is far from spicy. Do yourself a favor and go buy a premaid Masala sauce from Trader Joe's and cook yourself some rice and it will be far more tasty than what you get served here. We ordered our food spicy and could not feel a hint of spice anywhere in the dishes. The only nice thing about the food was the chutneys we got served as an appetizer that actually had some flavor.

The decor looks nice and all and you are led to belive that you would get a nice meal eating here but your are mistaken. Unless you like indian food that is not spicy. Then you might love it.
author: Oscar B.

description:
One word to describe this place: "meh"

I stopped by for lunch today, and their food was solidly unimpressive. It wasn't bad, just not much better than the Tasty Bite pre-prepared Indian meals you can buy at Trader Joe's. The onion kulcha didn't seem particularly fresh, and while the curry was fresh, it had some sort of a stock spice powder that overwhelmed the more subtle flavors.

Two positives - reasonably priced for such an elegant place (about $10-15/person, including a mango lassi), and a pretty nice ambience. The staff was also pretty friendly, but not impressive enough to overcome the overall mediocrity of the food.

In summary - Clay Oven is worth going to if you're in the area and really want Indian food, but I wouldn't travel across the city for it.
author: Sekhar S.

description:
As with other Indian restaurants in San Francisco, Clay Oven refuses to serve spicy food to white people, possibly to anyone at all, and so I give the restaurant a fairly low rating, despite everything else working out quite nicely.  My companions and I comprised a party of seven, and we had a large order, but all the dishes arrived in a timely and correct fashion, with the exception of the benghan bartha that my wife and I were sharing.  We had ordered it very spicy, and it was utterly bland, like all the other dishes.  The spiciest item we received was, in fact, the garlic naan.  The lamb saag ordered by another of my companions was pretty tasty, and the samosas and pakoras were all right, but the associated sauces were also pretty flavorless.

On the bright side, the service was extremely attentive, and we actually got multiple rounds of drinks, which has often been a problem at other Indian places, since finding a waiter after the food arrives can be difficult.  We lingered after dinner since the weather was cold and rainy, and the waiter brought us free chai tea, which was certainly a nice gesture.

On balance, however, I go to a restaurant for the food, and, on that basis, I just can't recommend Clay Oven.
author: Bitter J.

description: Two mamas and babies wandered in to Clay Oven for a late lunch and were greeted warmly by the waitstaff, who got us a table and fetched high chairs right away. We had the buffet, which was decent and tasty (particularly the chicken makhani) and relatively inexpensive, considering you can eat as much as you like. Both the babies loved the food, too, especially the saag paneer. We were in and out quickly, and the staff were cheerful about the fact that the babies had thrown food and cutlery on the floor and we weren't able to clean everything up. We really couldn't have asked for a better experience.
author: Beth W.

description:
I ordered food online-it said the delivery time was 45-60 minutes.  I had already paid and my card was charged. 

 I called them at 75minutes, "yeah yeah driver left, sorry; it will be there in 5-10 minutes."  15 minutes later (now 90minutes) I called the online service.  

They called restaurant, got same story...offered me a 10 bucks off next online order and promised a 5-10minute delivery time.  

The online Assistant stayed IM until her shift was over 35 minutes later.  the online service refunded me in full.  the food finally arrived 2 hours and 15 minutes after it was ordered.  It was cold.  it is now leftovers because at the 2-hour mark I broke down and ate cereal :'(

I guess this branch stays in business with walk-ins.  Do not, repeat DO NOT order delivery!
author: SD S.

description: We ordered delivery from this place at 7:45 and it didn't arrive until 9:45. Then when it did come, it wasn't that great- way too greasy. There are some restaurants that are a "maybe I got the wrong dish" kind of bad, but this place was a "never again" kind of bad.
author: andy f.

description:
this is the best Indian food in the city. It is just that simple. Yes it is pricey, yes delivery is slow. But so what? You could have super fast super cheap Indian food--that was not authentic and did not taste excellent but why bother? 

this is simply the best indian food in the city.
author: Vasile S.

description:
We were on our way to Deep Sushi, but when we arrived it was closed for the week. :-(  On our way home we decided to try the Clay Oven and were pleasantly surprised.  We ordered one of their Dinner for Two specials.  The amount of food was ridiculous for $40 and we will be having leftovers for days.  The atmosphere was nice and quiet and the food was not too heavy-which I find to be a constant problem with Indian food.  

All-in-all if you're in the neighborhood, I would definitely give it a try
author: kathryn t.

description: We love this place! It's great quality food and delicious. We often order food for delivery and it arrives pretty fast.
author: Susan C.

description: We were craving indian food and this is the only delivery I know in the area so we decided to give it another try. I even told the gentleman on the phone that we've had a disappointing experience but we'd like to give it another try. Alas, the results were the same. Proof that some people just shouldn't try the restaurant business.
author: Reza E.

description: Not very good at all.  Ordered delivery and it sucked.  The samosa were like mashed potatoes in a greasy shell.  The naan was chewy as if it were undercooked.  The lamb rogan josh wasn't very good.  Usually the sauce is savory and creamy, this wasn't like that.  The punjab chicken was as spicy as ordered and the best thing we got.  I also ordered a side of rice pilaf, which I expected to be a basmati rice w/ saffron, cardamom and peas.  What I received was mushy, overcooked white rice w/ peas.  That is crappy.  There will be no additional delivery orders and the quality of food doesn't make me what to go in to the restuarnt either.
author: Heather S.

description:
The food here is less oily than many of the Indian restaurants in the bay.  Their masala sauce is good and a little sweet.  The paneer was tasty and generous.  Another favorite here is the palak dal and garlic naan.  

The atmosphere and cleanliness of this restaurant is also superior to their competitors.  This is one of the better, not as "fast foodish" as many SF Indian restaurants, and therefore, is a little pricier than average, but I also can tell they are using higher quality ingredients.
author: Carla K.

description: Delicious, spicy, addictive food! The fish tikka masala is a must to try!
author: ralyv v.

description:
i'm an ok student.  not great, not bad.  for most of my academic life, the problem has been conduct.  no matter how hard i tried to sit still in a chair and not talk to those around me, i always got a D in conduct.  luckily, in college they don't grade you on conduct.  for the first time in my whole life, i got all A's (actually, i got 1 A-, but i'm not counting that).  i asked the old man for some money for all those A's, but instead i got dinner at clay oven.

we got takeout before game 1 of the NBA finals and ate in front of the tube.  we used an entertainment coupon for 25% off entire bill.  food was pretty solid.  we got veggie korma and a lamb special that was really good.

if i get all A's next semester, i want to go somewhere fancier and i want cash.  50 bucks an A sounds fair to me.
author: Katie H.

description: Flavorful indian food, rich & spicy chai, and a cozy dining experience await you at Clay Oven. I have enjoyed the lamb tikka masala and saffron flavored basmati rice here many times. This place is great for a date during the hectic work week. I also enjoyed carrot pudding here with my Mom when she was in town visiting. The staff welcomes everyone.
author: Sara L.

description: Chicken Tika Masala was great. Rice was horrible. Mushy overcooked rice, maybe its because we were the first dinner customers and got the lunch batch. Had them remake the rice, by the time it came we were finished with the meal. An Indian place that will serve overcooked rice to its customers, not coming back.
author: Gene K.

description:
let me start by saying that i really, really wanted to like this place.

but i didn't.

i was so excited to have an indian restaurant open in the 'hood and when we saw the sign, we went to dinner there the same day.  it started off well - we were seated promptly, had our order taken in a reasonable amount of time and our appetizers served relatively quickly.  then it all went downhill.

after an hour (!) of waiting for our entrees, and having asked for them a few times, we were ready to walk out the door.  the table next to us was asking the manager where their food was, and we overheard people a few tables over asking why they hadn't gotten their apps after 40 minutes of waiting.  the table next to us, who had ordered a good while after us, got two orders of chicken tikka delivered when they only wanted one.  i had a feeling the other one was ours, but it went back to the kitchen.  

we were literally grabbing our coats to head for the door when our food finally came with no apologies.  and cold.  and not very good.  the manager asked us, "so, how is everything?"  i said "cold."  he walked away.  hmmm.  not the response i was looking for. 

we took an order of aloo gobi to my sister - not because we wanted to subject her to the food, but because she was starving and we had promised.  five minutes after we dropped it off, she called me and asked, "how does something manage to be hot, spicy and flavorless all at the same time?" 

i'll give them a very small benefit of the doubt since they've only been open two weeks, but i'd wait before trying it out.  1 1/2 stars.  i would have given them two stars if it hadn't cost $60 - without alcohol.
author: Eryn K.

description: So so so bad....I actually joined Yelp just to write how bad this was. It was New Year's day 2008 and I was excited to start the new year off right , rent a movie, hang out in my pjs, and enjoy some indian delivery. it was awful. worst indian food i have ever had....and i love indian food! NOTHING we ordered was even remotely okay. DO NOT GO HERE!
author: Adrienne G.

description: I really like this place.  Maybe I'm desperate for good Indian food in my hood, but I think I've gotten over that enough to give an even review.  The owner and staff are really friendly.  I find the food tasty and flavorful.  My only issue is that while the protions are large (especially take-out), the prices are a bit high.  Soooo if you're ordering and want the typical variety of three dishes, you'll be spending quite a bit...and getting a good amount of leftovers for the next day.  I'll survive.
author: bill k.

description: Unlike the other reviews, I had an excellent time when I went here, however; this was on a weekday night. The food was some of the best Indian food I'd had and the service was decent. It's not very cheap (nor expensive), but you get your moneys worth. I'd say try it out on a less busy night, and dine-in here don't get delivery.
author: Annie H.

description: My husband and I liked it.  Food was well prepared and tasty.  It's a nice addition to Church Street.  The mus-ac was a little off--think elevator--but we dealt.  I would recommend the lamb masala and aloo gobi.
author: Ursinha G.

description: I don't remember exactly which curries we ordered, but they were disconcertingly sweet. I think the garlic naan was pretty good. But it doesn't really matter, I was too distracted away from the meal to write a decent review of the food. A child of one of the staff members child was inciting all of the other children in the restaurant to scream and jump around and touch the rest of the diner's. It was beyond absurd and continued from the moment was sat down past the end of our meal without a word from any of the staff. In a loud kid-friendly joint with plenty of space, fine. But this is a closet sized, candle-lit joint and I wanted a snuggley dinner with my love.
author: Danielle R.

description: Just OK.  No logistical issues with our pickup order.  Food wasn't bad, I just like Spicy Bite more in this area -- it's also a few bucks cheaper.
author: Nat K.

description: came here randomly one rainy night.  we were surprised to see the tables dressed with white linen, and roses.  we ordered our food spicy, and both came out very mild.  also, we had to ask for our naan after waiting 5 minutes after the meal was served.  i'm not sure if they forgot, but it took another 10 minutes to get them.  the food was okay, the servers were kind, but they're definitely in no rush.  the restaurant is a nice indian joint, so you're paying for the ambiance and the location in noe valley.  you could get the same dishes for half the price at (and much better, i dare say) your standard indian restaurants in the tenderloin.  but then again, it's about the location...
author: Sheri N.

description: This place was a good! idk why there were about 4 or 5 to-go orders while the restaurant itself is great.  The music and atmosphere was fine and the staff was always ready to serve. The food was great, i had a lamb dish and it was soo tender that i could cut it with a fork! i also had the tandoori chicken which was good and the coconut vegetable curry which was DELICIOUS! over rice ummmmm! For dessert i had rice pudding, which was very tasty and some of my bro's mango Ice cream, that did not taste fake and was a very soothing way to end a dinner. I had no problem with this place at all, definitely go again
author: Travis G.

description: Every time I crave Indian food and good naan bread, I stop by this restaurant on Church Street.  I worry because it's never full, you can always get a table.  Maybe the portions are too small for the price, but the food is delicious.  My Oakland co-workers make me bring their chicken tiki masala to work, they can't find a comparable sauce in the East Bay.  A BUFFET lunch is available now -maybe to bring in more customers?!? That's when I go, for $8.95 I get to sample everything and go back for more. Lamb, tandori chicken, tiki masala, rice, vegetables, naan bread, dessert...I could eat that food everyday!
author: Paula F.

description: The delivery service was great, except the Okra dish I ordered was extremely salty and stringy because of old Okra.  The nan was decent, but never going to order Okra from there again.
author: Xu D.

description:
We had several positive dining in experiences at Clay Oven when they first opened in our neighborhood, so we figured that the take out would be equally delicious.  WRONG!   After three tries now, the take out has been sub par (read: bland) and this last time we ordered they Overcharged us! and the delivery guy asked for a bigger tip. 
We love Indian food, and now we will go elsewhere for it.
author: Doreen P.

description: Clay Oven is in our hood so we have ordered from them several times both pick up and delivery. The portions are decent sized. We seem to always have leftovers. The dishes we've tried have always been delicious including lamb or chicken tikka masala, bengan bhartha, alloo gobi, and sag paneer. Once our naan was burnt and  that was disappointing but typically we enjoy our meal.
author: Romeo And Lola K.

description: Went there twice this month. Despite asking for the hottest most lunatic spicy curry they could muster, both times were quite mild. The waiters there are so nice, but they mess up. They served the wrong dishes to each of us and didn't know which was which. One time they also serve the starters with the main course. In fairness to them they gave us a little free desert but the bill was still huge. Decent food but relatively expensive.
author: Gary G.

description: This place would get 2 stars except the atmosphere is nice. Its not grungy like a lot of Indian restaurants, and the music is the typical bollywood but its not blasting. Food is okay, but I'm not sure I'd go back unless I'm desperate for Indian and don't feel like leaving Noe.
author: Emily A.

description: Beautiful, romantic interior, and excellent food too. Prices are fair. I recommend highly.
author: Jade P.

description:
Why don't they have a lunch buffet? Is Noe Valley THAT much of a yuppie guppie burb that a lunch buffet would be too passe? Well, I happen to like Noe Valley decently enough, and this restaurant does fine without a lunch buffet. 

I came here for the lunch specials, and I was only moderately satisfied with my order. Dinner was a different experience, though. I came here straight from home, wearing only sweats and a book as my only company, but I felt at home in the dim, classy surroundings. The staff could stand to be a little more outgoing, though --- sometimes I felt like they were hawks, waiting to unseat me just in case I might fly the coop. No "how's the mushroom masala tonight"? No "ah, I see that you basically just rolled out of a late afternoon nap to have dinner at our fine establishment. Bravo!"  Maybe I shouldn't have came in my sweats after all. 

But the mushroom masala was good, and even better was the Kashmiri nan. I've never had nan of that kind before, and it was amazing... a bit sweet, though, and might work better as a dessert bread. (Also, the crust was a bit too burned for my liking. Work on that!) 

Speaking of dessert, what did I do to deserve the tasty rice pudding freebie at the end of my meal? I didn't notice any other tables getting any. Were they trying to get rid of curdling leftovers and saw my youthful demeanor as an excuse to unload it on me? Eh, it was a nice surprise. No sense questioning kindness.
author: Joseph R.

description: Take my review with a grain of salt -- I've never had Indian food in the US that I thought was very good after living in London for a year and was completely spoiled (don't even get me started on how good their Indian food is!).  Here, I find it all bland, dishes too similar to each other, and a bit of a yawn.  However, I'm glad that Noe has an Indian place now, and when you just really want some naan and a nice korma, this isn't your worst option.  I prefer to take-out from there.
author: Jenn K.

description: Damn. I should have checked the reviews before going here. I was so excited to finally have Indian food in the neighborhood. I got the Lamb Tikka Masala, Veggie Byrani, and Bhengen Bharta. They were all awful. So bad that I could not even bother to save them for leftovers.
author: Eater S.

description:
Yummmy!!!  So good!  I went here today for lunch and it was perfect.  Great prices too, my lunch special was $7.95 and comes with an entree, rice and small salad, great deal.  The naan, which I ordered separate, was perfect, light, crispy and a nice flavor.  All the dishes were so delicious.  

I really like the Prawn Tika Masala, the sauce is so tasty, the spinach with cheese cubes, and peas with cheese cubes.  Everything I've ever ordered here has been really good.
author: Anna Z.

description: I went for a late weekend lunch.  The service was fine, but we were the only customers, so I can't really rate it.  The food was amazing though.  I ordered samosas and bengan bartha. The bartha was the best I have ever had.  The prices were a little steep, but not unreasonable.
author: Gabe K.

description: Like many of the other reviewers, I am very excited to have an Indian Clay Oven in the neighborhood.  We tried it for the first time tonight.  The food was fine, exactly what you would expect from one of the Clay Ovens.  The decor is beautiful and the restaurant is comfortable.  We had several vegetable dishes and were happy with them all.  I would note, however, that despite the fact we ordered food "medium spicy" it was very mild (but flavorful).  If you live in the neighborhood, consider this a 4 star (the fourth star for convenience).
author: Penelope M.

description: Food was flavorless, service was horrible took 20 minutes after I was clearly done for the waiter to get off the phone and bring me the check!!! Then within an hour I felt tummy sick. Yeah, no thank you! Noe Valley is in desperate need of a GOOD indian restaurant.
author: ariana m.

description: Food was just OK.  I live 5 blocks away.  Ordered at 6 PM and was told 40 minutes for delivery.  OK.  I called after one hour and they said he would be right there in 5 minutes.  Ok.  Just got the food at 8:51 PM.  Cold and soggy.  Never again.
author: John F.

description:
it's about time our neighborhood opened up an Indian food restaurant. The food and service are always wonderful. I wish them all the best and hope that they never leave. 

Thank you!
author: DEANNA R.

description:
First I think the food here is good. I love the velvet butter chicken. When we learned they delivered we started ordering from them at least once a month. 
Tonight, however, that has ended and we will not be ordering from them again. There have been some problems the last few times we got deliveries. Mostly the problems were delivering the wrong food. They always corrected the problem but never offered a discount or anything for free. We like the food so much that we put up with it.
Tonight we got the wrong food three times. After the third time I called them and after a little bit of a struggle with the owner/boss he promised a 20% discount and new food. However, they sent the driver without a new credit card receipt and even though he assured us it would be taken care of we decided not to chance it. We sent the food back. Called them and demanded a refund. Now we wait to see if the refund goes through. It was such a frustrating experience. Normally we are very patient but after the last times we have ordered and it has been wrong we cannot be patient anymore. 
It is too bad for us because we really like their food. 
It is too bad for them because we were good customers and we use to recommend them to our friends.
author: T W.

description: bottom line; good curry. a bit on the pricier side when compared to other northern indian/pakistani joints in the vicinity, but it was well worth it. the chutneys were fresh and tasty, my samosas were nice and crispy and my entree was good. i ordered the chicken tikka masala (i know, not exactly the most adventurous choice, but one of my faves), the sauce was spicy and savory and the meat was nice and tender. i thought it was nice how they brought out a mini chaffing dish for my entree. the naan was fresh, hot and perfectly fluffy. the service was also prompt and courteous. I also liked the fact they have my favorite Indian beer, flying horse; a nice hoppy lager to cut through all the spice. not a place i'd get takeout to curb a late night curry cravin', but a great joint to treat yourself to once in a while of take a date to.
author: cyrus t.

description: our cheese dish was lovely and fresh light cheese,lamb korma a bit tough but divine sauce,3 more dishes all degree of spice requested and great sauces.pekora a little tired but onion cake great. will go back anytime.very much appreciate the civilized noise level
author: Sharon s.

description: The roomies and I tried out grubhub.com for the first time on Friday night. We get lazy and then have to order in, and then it's always chinese or pizza, pizza or chinese. So yay when grubhub suggested this place. Delivery is cash only through them, but it may be different if you order direct. You can place your order right online. The  menu looks good, I had a very hard time deciding.. I ended up with a lamb dish that has apricots in it. It was so good! The portion was large; I wasn't even able to finish the last few bites, and I have a big apetite. B had a garlic lamb dish which he liked too. He ordered mild but still thought it was a bit spicy. Mine wasn't spicy, but I forget if I asked for medium or hot.  I thought b's was good, but mine was better. His food lasted him two days, and he has a fairly normal apetite. J had the lamb saag and s had the chicken saag. Very tasty. The basmati rice was yummy, the naan was nice and plump.  The mango lassis were good, but not great. Overall, we really enjoyed the meal, and it was about $15 per person all together which is well priced. I know a lot of the reviews on here say it is expensive, but we were actually thinking as we were ordering it, that it was cheap. Delivery came fast, the food was still hot. I think we will go back again. I love indian food and this is much better than the place I went on my birthday, although maybe less good than the place I went before... Factoring in the fact that this was takeout, I think it was great.
author: Merredith L.

description: I received delivery from here....and the Tandoori Chicken was greasy...and the Chicken Tikka Masala arrived cold.  I have eaten in and had a better experience....but I am not a fan of delivery.
author: Sarah S.

description: ate here yesterday for a fun girls-only brunch.  we were the only people in the entire restaurant!  we ordered a bunch of vegetarian dishes to share.  everything was great and service was great too, although again, we were the only people in the place so it would have been hard to give bad service.  naan was delicious, and so was the bengan bhartha and coconut vegetable curry.  they even made us our own saag chana because it wasn't on the menu.  can't wait to try the other locations.
author: kate s.

description: great time. the food took a while to come, but that was fine. it was the third night that they were open, and i was in no hurry. kashmiri fish was the best of the five dishes that i tasted. the coconut curry was great too. all of the service was great and i would suggest this to friends so long as they did not want a quick dinner. great addition to the neighborhood i grew up in. much better than china pepper, and not too pricey compared to some of the other newish spots in UPPER NOE VALLEY.
author: Morgan W.

description: We were pretty underwhelmed by the Clay Oven.  Interestingly, our friends thought it was delicious, which was curious since we were eating family style.  I didn't think anything was terrible, but nothing was very good and I found myself wishing I had opened a box of tasty bite instead.  The rice was made of all broken pieces.  The garlic naan was made with garlic powder, not actual garlic, which made it powdery and bitter.  And, the service was terrible.  Aside from the person who took our order, no one seemed to know what was going on, when we asked the waiter that brought our food if we could order some wine he had no idea what we were talking about.  Anyway, to each his own, but I wouldn't make any effort to eat here again.
author: Jessica T.

description: the food was solid, tasty and delivered in under 45 mins, one of the few places in SF that has Vegetable kofta, lost a star because the potatoes in the saag could have been a little firmer, less over-cooked but altogether a good experience, and certainly right for the price
author: Jared Z.

description: like others, i was so excited to have a  new indian place in the hood. it's good, but not great - as others have said, it's lacking spice, though not really flavor. next time, i'll specify spicy and maybe they'll earn a fourth star.
author: Erica W.

description: clay oven is a great addition to the neighborhood - much better than the weird bistro that previously was in this space.  their chicken tikki masala and veggie coconut curry are both tasty, as are their veggie samosas.  true, they are not as good as spicy bite, but if you want to actually eat at the restaurant, rather than just order take out, this place is a good bet.
author: Erin C.

description: I have to say I was quite pleased with this newer restaurant in the Noe area.  The chicken was absolutely perfect.  Tender, Juicy and just the right amount of spice.  The service was very good. I really have no complaints, I'm just happy to have a really good Indian/Paki rest. in the neighborhood.
author: Josh L.

description: I have ordered take out from Clay Oven several times and have always enjoyed it very much.  Food is delicious.  However, I felt compelled to share a recent experience a girlfriend and I had when we ate there a few weeks ago.  We ordered the homemade pickles appetizer (or something to that effect) and a while later (service was not great and we were the only customers there) we were brought some flatbread and a dish of what looked like some kind of chutney.  Forgetting that we had ordered an appetizer, I thought this was just what they brought to every table like bread and butter.  So we tried it and it was probably the most disgusting thing I have ever tasted.  I could barely swallow it.  We were so perplexed by how awful it was that we started laughing hysterically.  I almost complained but decided not to as we didn't want to offend them.  Everything else was delicious, thank god.  I had leftovers to take home and I noticed they had included the vile "chutney" with the rest of my food.  I asked my boyfriend, a chef, to taste it just to tell me what he thought and he could not even swallow it.  His guess was too much vinegar was used to pickle whatever it was (vegetables I think) and they did not taste it beforehand.  Poor quality control.  Of course, there is the possibility that that is how it is supposed to taste so if that is the case, I would STRONGLY recommend NOT ordering the pickles appetizer at Clay Oven.  You will thank me.  Seriously.
author: Knitgirl P.

description: like other people, i really wanted to like this place, because it's nice having an indian place in the hood.  but, the food was terrible. in lieu of real flavor, they unleashed a firehose of red hot spice onto all the dishes.  blech.  and yes, overpriced.
author: soph q.

description: I went to this restaurant last night with my husband. We are really happy to have them as the newest noe valley addition. The service was really great, the manager served us I believe, and their was never a dirty dish left on our table - never a glass of water that wasn't filled. We were not rushed to order, nor to pay. I am not sure why the restaurant is getting so many terrible reviews, maybe it is becuase they had just opened, but I really had a great experience. I have to say though, I am not a spicy fan, so maybe for others it needs more spice, for me it was perfect. I recommend the mango lassi's they are delicious! - They could serve a fuller glass of chai however, as it seemed only half full in the cup I got, but that was my only gripe. We ordered the vegetable samosa's, cucumber salad, vegetable korma, rice, chicken tikka masala, two mango lassi's, and a chai tea. Nice people too, and the restaurant was packed.
author: ac P.

description: everytime i have been here the food is very good.  my issue is the service.  it is either very odd, or last time pretty non-existent.  my husband and i were basically the only people in the restaurant but our food and even finding someone to take our order took FOREVER.  there were plenty of people working, but perhaps they just couldn't see us?
author: n. h.
